CatDescriptText: Cutline of related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 24, 1944, pg. 13, reads: "...Right: Snub Mosley and his latest collection of musicians who are currently dispensing their rhythms far from the Great White Way in a spot near Pittsburgh. With the trend toward small combos, Snub's outfit is well up among the leaders of small bands.  Snub's is one of the best style combos in business - Harris photo."  Portion of accompanying article reads: "Snub Mosley Fronts One of Best Combos - Snub Mosley, wizard of the slide saxophone and trombone, is currently fronting the best combo of his career at the Club Brazil, which is located a short distance from Pittsburgh.  Snub and his gang have been operating at the spot for more than two months.  The band line-up includes: H. G. Godley, drums; Irving (Smiley) Trotman, piano; Jimmy LaRosa, bass; Robert Carroll, trumpet, and Herman Flintall and Specs Thomas, reeds.  One of the hottest lookers in the business is Snub's vocalist, June Eckstein [Eckstine], wife of Billy Eckstein [sic]."
TitMainTitle: Snub Mosley band, including vocalist June Eckstine on left, and possibly including Herman Flintall or Specs Thomas on saxophone, Robert Carroll on trumpet, Snub Mosley on trombone, Irving "Smiley" Trotman on piano, Jimmy LaRosa on bass, and H. G. Godley on drums, in Club Brazil, Houston, Pennsylvania, another version
